subject: European Integration History and Swiss-EU Relations
key_concepts: Three dimensions of European integration: institutional depth, sectoral breadth, territorial expansion
Key treaties and milestones (Rome 1957, Maastricht 1993, Lisbon 2009)
Differentiated integration and EU competence order (Articles 3, 4, 6 AEUV)
Historical development of Swiss-EU relations and bilateral agreements
Early European visions (Coudenhove-Kalergi, Briand Plan, Ventotene Manifesto)
Institutional crises and solutions (Luxembourg Compromise 1966, Santer Commission resignation 1999)
Major EU crises (Eurozone, migration, Brexit, Ukraine war)
Foundational legal principles (direct effect, supremacy of EU law)
EU enlargement waves and territorial expansion timeline
why_exam_relevance: This document contains foundational historical knowledge essential for understanding current EU structures and Swiss-EU relations. The seminar explicitly prepares for a final exam combining multiple-choice and open questions. The material covers both theoretical frameworks (three dimensions of integration) and concrete historical events that are frequently tested in European studies exams. The timeline approach provides essential chronology for comparative questions.
likely_exam_questions: Compare and contrast early European visions (Coudenhove-Kalergi vs. Schuman Declaration)
Analyze the three dimensions of European integration using specific historical examples
Explain the significance of key legal cases (Van Gend en Loos 1963, Costa v. Enel 1964)
Trace the development of EU competences from sectoral to comprehensive integration
Discuss how crises have shaped European integration (provide 3 examples)
Map the territorial expansion of the EU and its political consequences
Analyze the Schuman Declaration: economic vs. political motivations
Explain differentiated integration using the Swiss-EU relationship as a case study
Connect historical milestones to current EU challenges (e.g., 2005 constitutional rejection to current reform debates)
Compare the founding approaches of Monnet ('Europe through crises') with contemporary integration challenges
connections: EU legal principles and competence order (Session 3)
EU foreign policy and enlargement policy
difficulty_spikes: Understanding the three-dimensional framework of integration (institutional, sectoral, territorial) and applying it to historical events
Distinguishing between different early European visions (federalist vs. functionalist approaches)
Comprehending the legal principles of direct effect and supremacy in historical context
Analyzing the competence order (Articles 3, 4, 6 AEUV) and its evolution
Connecting historical crises to institutional developments (e.g., Luxembourg Compromise to current decision-making)
prerequisites: Basic knowledge of post-WWII European history
Understanding of key international organizations (Council of Europe)
Basic concepts of international relations and sovereignty
Knowledge of Swiss political system (for Swiss-EU context)
summary: This introductory seminar session provides a chronological overview of European integration from early 20th century visions to contemporary challenges. It establishes a three-dimensional analytical framework (institutional depth, sectoral breadth, territorial expansion) for understanding integration dynamics. The material connects historical milestones with current EU structures and introduces the Swiss-EU relationship as a case study of differentiated integration. Key emphasis is placed on crisis-driven development and the evolution from sectoral to comprehensive integration.
